channel.title: Technical Growth on Figuring it Out

item.title: Learning GA4 and Rediscovering the Joy of Growth
item.description:
Last week, I earned my first new certification in years: Google Analytics, offered through Google Skillshop. And let me tell youâ€”it felt SO GOOD. From watching the videos and taking notes, to studying for the final exam, to finally passing and posting that shiny little badge on LinkedIn, I felt a sense of pride that I hadnâ€™t experienced in a while.

I finally got to be the one to say: “I’m happy to share that I…”

But beyond the badge, Iâ€™m proud of something deeper: the small, intentional choices I made that allowed me to chip away at the coursework despite a jam-packed schedule. Choosing to log in instead of doomscroll. Prioritizing my own growth alongside my responsibilities as a manager. Investing in myself again.

Itâ€™s not that I havenâ€™t been learningâ€”stepping into management, navigating a new tech stack, and entering the world of e-commerce was like jumping off a cliff into deep water. But this was different. This was structured, focused learning that I chose. And it reminded me how much I missed that.

Understanding Google Analytics 4 was a key step for me as a leader. Iâ€™d never worked with SEO beforeâ€”didnâ€™t even realize how closely it ties into software development and data collection. I used to sit silently in meetings while our product managers and engineers discussed upcoming tagging work or issues with a poorly performing page. Iâ€™d listen, absorb, and nod… but rarely contribute.

Now? After just one certification, Iâ€™ve already seen the impact. We just wrapped up our Q2 Big Room Planning, and for the first time, I was able to ask intelligent questions about data collection strategies for a new set of pages weâ€™re rolling out. I even caught a user flow issue that hadnâ€™t been considered yetâ€”and suggested a tagging approach to help track it.

It felt empowering.

The combination of new knowledge and immediate application was an absolute rush. I remembered how curiosity, when nurtured, turns into confidence.

And now Iâ€™m hooked. Iâ€™m ready to keep going. But what next?

Should I dive into Google Cloud Platform (GCP) training to get more comfortable with the infrastructure side of things? Are there deeper SEO-related topicsâ€”like structured data, schema markup, or Lighthouse auditsâ€”that I should explore? What would help me show up even stronger for my team and our cross-functional partners?

If youâ€™ve recently learned something new that shifted how you work, Iâ€™d love to hear about it. Letâ€™s trade notes. Or if youâ€™ve taken GCP or SEO courses you really liked, send them my way.

Hereâ€™s to the next learning curve. Iâ€™m ready.

âœ¨ Got suggestions for what I should learn next?
Drop them in the comments, message me on LinkedIn, or send a carrier pigeon. Iâ€™m seriousâ€”I want to hear whatâ€™s helped you grow. Letâ€™s build a little learning community together.

And if youâ€™ve been putting off that course, certification, or passion project? This is your nudge. Start today. A little at a time adds up, I promise.

item.title: Building the Foundation: Lessons and Wins from Blog Iteration One
item.description:
One purpose of this blog is to make sure Iâ€™m keeping my hands on the keyboard so I donâ€™t drift too far from coding, even though Iâ€™ve transitioned into a management role. Truthfully, itâ€™s been nearly three years since Iâ€™ve coded with any real focus, and, well, Iâ€™ve forgotten a lot.

Writing this post also pushes me out of my comfort zone by doing something I find challenging: documenting my technical skillset and confronting where I fall short. Iâ€™ve never been great at not being great at something, and software development often feels like â€œgoing against the grainâ€ for me. It doesnâ€™t help that I work with some incredibly talented developersâ€”comparing my skills to theirs feels like dropping a stone in my stomach.

That said, this blog is about growth. And I know Iâ€™ll never expand my boundaries if I donâ€™t push against them.

Blog 1.0

The blog youâ€™re reading now is actually my second full build and deploy. When I first spun up a Hugo project, I struggled to get my theme-of-choice to work. Instead of dwelling in that discomfort (noticing a trend?), I decided to build and style everything myself.

The result? Functional but awful. I had a homepage, an About page, post pages, and an article list, but it all looked a little bit like my MySpace circa 2004. Once I deployed it, I immediately knew it wasnâ€™t my best work.

A UX designer, I am not.

So, I scrapped it all, read up on Hugo themes, and voilÃ â€”here we are. This version feels much more polished and streamlined, and Iâ€™m excited to keep iterating on it.

Friction points and Takeaways

There were definitely some bumps along the way. Here are the biggest challenges and lessons learned:

  • Remembering CSS. I donâ€™t miss fiddling with selectors and flexbox, but nothing beats the rush of seeing something finally look like the idea in your head after 20 minutes of tinkering in the browser inspector.
  • Reading technical documentation. I struggle with reading through dense technical docsâ€”it sometimes feels like decoding another language. Hugoâ€™s structure took me longer to understand than Iâ€™d care to admit, but persistence paid off. Now, I know where to put things to make them work as intended.
  • Deployment. This blog is currently deployed via GitHub Pages, which Iâ€™m familiar with. However, I wanted to use GCP to align with the tooling my team works with. My first attempt failed (likely a DNS configuration issue), so I pivoted to get the blog up and running. Iâ€™ll circle back to GCP deployment soon.
  • ChatGPT Wow. If this had existed when I was learning to code, I wonder how it would have shaped my career. It helped me clear several hurdles, but Iâ€™m also grappling with whether itâ€™s becoming a crutch. Generative AI is just another toolâ€”like a calculatorâ€”but I canâ€™t help but wonder what I might miss by relying on it too much.

Status Update

Here’s where things stand after this iteration:

To Do ğŸ“‹ Completed âœ… Revisit â™»ï¸
Add GA 4 tracking Deploy Blog GCP deployment
Make SEO improvements First post Hugo documentation
Investigate metadata and update Add newsletter sign up
Add Disqus for comments
Promote on LinkedIn

This journey has already been a learning experience, and Iâ€™m looking forward to iterating further.

Have you tackled a similar project? Struggled with CSS selectors or documentation that felt like another language? Iâ€™d love to hear about your experiences! Drop your thoughts, tips, or questions in the comments belowâ€”Iâ€™m excited to learn from you, too.

Stay tuned as I keep figuring it out!
